comments.text:
+Adam Barber
Here's what I think SR could have done to be better:
-Multiple maps:  Playing on the same map can be rather stale.  Don't really 
need a specific theme, just a different design.  I always find myself, out 
of habbit, returning to the cave section.

-Final Brawl Times: I am *NOT* a fan of 1 minute brawls.  It is not enough 
time to display all the stats that I have collected.  Here's what I would 
change:  no time limit on stock brawls, 2 minute on timed brawls, two stock 
on "Glorious Smash."

-Some franchises have more enemies:  I like the number and variety from 
Mario/Kirby/LoZ/KI.  But I think maybe Metroid/DK/Earthbound/Pikmin could 
have benefited from more enemies.  I don't know the franchises well enough 
to list off specifics, but if it was too hard to narrow down without flat 
out copying, I understand.

-Need Moar Koffings:  This is just bias.  Seriously, I love that toxic 
goofball.  :3
comments.author: Lucky Koopa

comments.text:
+Adam Barber
I'll try to address all your points while adding my own flavor.
-Time:  I feel that 5 minutes is just enough.  4 is too little, 6 is too 
much.

-Enemy interaction:  This is a feature that either you think it's useful, 
or it isn't.  Yes, you could interfere with enemies getting all the 
powerups, and you could KO them.  But enemies already add enough difficulty 
to do that.  Plus, all interaction is saved for the final brawl (I'll touch 
on this later)

-Enemies/FInal events:  This is personal taste for the former, so not much 
to say.  But for both, I like the randomness.  I can win a jump race with 
Ganondorf/Mac or a speed race with DK.  Just comes down to how bad the luck 
of the AI is vs. your own.  Just comes down to skill at that point.  Defeat 
as many enemies mode is a good addition, at least it's action.  But I must 
stress:  BEWARE PARASOL DEE ARMY!  XD

-No online:  This one is where I'll be blunt; Smash Run would be HORRIBLE 
online with the time length to consider.  Why?  People play with bad 
connections.  The result?  Lag.  I don't know about you, but I don't want 
to play a game either waiting for someone's connection to stabilize or for 
someone to finish their run.  Now I know what you're thinking:  Time could 
be lower, right?  Still have the connection to deal with, plus a short time 
isn't alot to explore as far as possible/get as many powerups as possible.

I think that Smash Run is great for what it is, but there are ways that it 
could have been better:  I'll make a different comment for it.
comments.author: Lucky Koopa

+Noponis Confirmation bias, and general societal issues of flight from 
facts. This is what seems to be the core things Melee fans hate the most 
about the plethora of Brawl now Sm4sh players. They clearly show they have 
no clue about core mechanics, such as physics, hit stun, hit boxes, frame 
data or anything of the likes. Not to mention the fact that most of these 
people have only just got into smash competitively, and with the ignorance 
of mechanics I mentioned before, think they are these beacons of 
competitive gaming knowledge. 

There is quite literally nothing you or I could ever say that would make 
95% of these people think any differently, because they don't understand, 
nor care to understand what the core physics, and mechanics of the games 
really are. Whats funny about all of this is that Brawl and Sm4sh owe all 
their dregs of hype to Melee. A game in which its competitive fans have 
grass rooted tournaments for 14 years, developed an ever evolving meta, 
discovering new and deep tech that allows for more options, and have been 
shat on by Nintendo the whole time. 

It's so ironic that people hate on Melee so much when their competitive 
scenes are suckling from Melee born tournament culture. I don't honestly 
care if people enjoy Smash Wii U on a personal "I enjoy playing derpy with 
items on, in rng infested stages with my friends" thats fine, all the power 
to you, but it annoys the crap out of me that people think they suddenly 
can jump in the middle of the scene and act like they just know it all 
because they are local champs, and beat all their friends.

comments.text:
There's a difference between keeping gameplay but adding new mechanics, and 
keeping gameplay and adding a bare minimum to call it a new game. SSB4 of 
all things is an example of the first one, the new movesets had quite a bit 
of thought put into them, and the roster is actually surprisingly balanced. 
CoD is a yearly release that really only changes in title, so that's 
definitely a point against it.

A game's formula should stay consistent, but there should be enough added 
to make it feel like a new experience. People only really buy CoD because 
the online population is moving over to the next game, which happens every 
year, but Smash is only released once every system.

comments.text:
Even something as simple as more texture options makes custom content more 
interesting. I've built custom stages in TimeSplitters FP, every Halo with 
Forge, and Brawl, and generally more tools result in better stage quality 
and variety. Also, as someone who does casual image editing, the ability to 
drag and drop shapes is a basic feature; if you've worked to make a 
specific shape and finally made it perfect, it's a shame to have to erase 
it to move its position. Things like this should be as user-friendly and 
feature-rich as possible so that they're not tedious or bland.

with spikes or ice and now they can't. You can draw platforms, but how do

ladders, not even Danger Zones or an option to color the platforms you draw

make anything remotely good with it, and to say that people who can't make 
good stages with less things to work with than the past game ( which's 
Stage Builder was ridiculed for having limited capabilities) have no 
imaginations is a severe overstatement.

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
Perhaps I should not have used the word hardcore, but I do feel the 
in-depth, endless skill of Smash is more hardcore personally than the 
chaotic free-for-alls. Forget I used that word, it's not really relevant to 
what I was writing since that's another topic altogether and pretend I just 
wrote competitive.

I did say that if your experience differed, I would respect that, though 
I'd say those people aren't really that competitive, they just are 
competitive wannabees.

By being so close, I didn't mean in terms of non-hazarded stages. I meant 
Omega was so close to the right thought process. Sakurai had the right idea 
and was doing his best to please us, he just went about it the wrong way. 
And a LOT of the stages in this game aren't viable for competitive play, 
between being too large, walkoffs, or having plenty of non-boss hazards to 
get in the way. Most of the stages are out of the question for competitive 
play. Builder won't even be considered for a variety of reasons, biggest 
being that it's not the kind of stage one can prepare for combat on, since 
in a tournament setting, it will likely be the first time one of the 
players is ever seeing that stage. Again, the options are limited. You 
can't do something like Wily's Castle's moving platforms in builder.

I think you aren't understanding what my complaint really is. It's not so 
much that the stages are gimmicky, it's that Sakurai came up with the wrong 
solution to gimmicks. Omega mode was an idea that he thought would solve 
the problem, but it wasn't. How is that not valid?
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti First of all, competitive =/= hardcore, if anything those 
who play WITH stage hazards are the hardcore ones. Secondly, Omega mode 
wasn't made for competitive players; it was made so everyone who always 
played on Final Destination in previous titles would still get to listen to 
all the music and see all the cool scenery the stages had to offer. And no, 
it doesn't suck.

"I see so many casual players hating on competitive players and have rarely 
seen competitive players actually complaining like they are stereotyped to 
do."

Maybe you need to frequent more videos then? And most competitive players 
are smarmy elitists, which is the kind of person I don't want as a friend.

"I think a lot of them (me included) are just frustrated that Sakurai came 
so close this time around to giving us exactly what we wanted in the way of 
stages only to make one mistake that completely negated the effects of the 
effort."

Which just provides more evidence to my previous assessment. Dude, you've 
already got plenty of hazard-less, not counting the infinite possibilities 
of the Builder, stages to choose from! Ignore Omega mode, fine. Wily 
Castle, Pyrosphere, and Gaur Plain are only three stages out of a selection 
of, like, fifty or something, many of which are viable for competitive 
play. You have no valid complaints, end of story.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
Stage Builder won't let me do cool platform things or anything.

Voicing my opinion does bring others to disagree, which they can do 
respectfully (I feel you haven't been, whether or not that was 
intentional), and then debated. Would a hazard switch have hurt you? Are 
you honestly against one? You haven't disagreed with my opinion so much as 
you have told me to just shut up, which isn't the same thing.

I've said in other comments (and if I haven't said it on this specific 
conversation, I'll say it now), I play casually and will enjoy the Devil 
then. I appreciate Sakurai trying to appeal to the hardcore players with 
Omega mode, even if it wasn't the right way to do that. Doesn't change the 
fact that a hazard switch would have been really appreciated and a much 
better choice than Omega Mode. I didn't say it should never have been 
there, I said I didn't like it. I did say Omega sucks, because it does, but 
once more, I appreciate that Sakurai at least tried.

I see so many casual players hating on competitive players and have rarely 
seen competitive players actually complaining like they are stereotyped to 
do. If your experience truly differs, I'll respect that, but most 
competitive players aren't that hard to get along with and do share similar 
views to what I'm describing here.

I think a lot of them (me included) are just frustrated that Sakurai came 
so close this time around to giving us exactly what we wanted in the way of 
stages only to make one mistake that completely negated the effects of the 
effort.
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti 1. Tough shit if you like those layouts more. Then again,

all of whom will agree with you. 3. If you meant to voice it respectfully, 
a better way of doing so would've been something akin to the following: 
"While I can appreciate an attempt to make a stage a bit more interesting, 
Yellow Devil frustrates me too much for me to feel any in his case. 
Hopefully, Smash 5 will find a way to remedy this." Instead, what you wrote 
basically amounted to: "This sucks. I hate it. It shouldn't have existed to 
begin with!" It's the latter kind of response that I've been seeing from 
all the competitive players, and it gets really irritating after a while so 
of course I was going to rant when it became unbearable. You were just 
unlucky enough to be the straw which broke the camel's back, and while I 
apologize for lashing out at you, my points still stand.

comments.text:
+Beck D. The competitive scene doesn't really care about good graphics, 
more so good gameplay. I mean, Melee, which is an early Gamecube game, 
still is played the most. We do, however, care about 60 fps (so there is no 
input delay). Good characters goes for everyone, not just competitive 
players. People don't really care too much about Doc. Mewtwo got pretty 
much everyone hyped. For Glory mode is a bit of a disappointment, because 
it gives a false portrayal of competitive players (no items, fox only, 
final destination). Omega stages are literally just Final destination, once 
again giving a false portrayal of the competitive community. The funny 
thing is, with the counter pick system in tournaments (Winner of previous 
match bans one stage choice, or however many in the Wii U version, Loser 
picks the next stage, and you are not allowed to counter pick any stage you 
have won on in that set), Final Destination and all Omega forms are put as 
one stage (because they are basically the same stage), meaning that you 
only get to use Omega forms once per set. And Gamecube controllers were for 
pretty much everyone, as plenty of people who played Melee (casuals and 
competitives alike) used Gamecube controllers in Brawl, so naturally, those 
people would want to use a gamecube controller. And in the end, while it is 
a bit disappointing to not have the option to just turn stage hazards off, 
the fact that a few stages have bosses doesn't make us hate the game. I 
mean, Melee only has six tournament legal stages (Final Destination, 
Battlefield, Yoshi's Story, Dreamland 64, Fountain of Dreams, and Pokemon 
Stadium).

comments.text:
You get it! Give this person a cookie because they actually get it. 
Adventure mode and the Subspace Emissary were really lame and unnecessary 
platforming challenges interlaced with pseudo combat and cutscenes.

Smash Bros. was never really meant to be any kind of Single Player 
experience. From the beginning, and throughout every iteration, Sakurai has 
fully intended for it to be a multiplayer party game. Even if you don't 
treat it that way, like if you play Smash in a more hardcore manner like 
competitively, then still, it's a fighting game, which in its very nature, 
requires multiplayer.
Sure, Subspace was a ~nice~ addition, I guess. But it was very hollow and 
lacking depth, and lacked true challenge or variety or incentive beyond, 
"Oh boy I can't wait to see the next cutscene!" But even beyond that, 
Sakurai already expressed his disapproval of making another thing like it 
because all those cutscenes just get spoiled onto the internet, so you 
don't even have to play through it to see them, and now your only incentive 
for playing it is arbitrary intrinsic challenge, like speed runs or 
clearing on hard mode. Otherwise, it's something most players beat once or 
twice and never come back to again, because there's no point. It was just a 
very long mediocre platforming course interspersed with cutscenes and light 
easter eggs. 
Modes like Smash Run and Smash Tour on the other hand completely and 
totally embody Sakurai's goals with this iteration. Smash Run lends itself 
well to bite sized rounds of Chaotic Smash Bros play well suited for a 
mobile experience. Smash Tour on the other hand, not unlike Mario Party, is 
perfect for a handful of friends to sit down at home and play a round or 
two of equally chaotic Smash. And BOTH have a lot of replay value, 
especially in comparison with Subspace Emissary.
Party play. Multiplayer. Chaos. You want a mechanically varied and 
technically replete platformer story thing, Smash Bros is not the place for 
it.
comments.author: Brandon Graham

comments.text:
I agree there shouldn't have been like, the story mode Brawl had. As cool 
as it was and as much fun as I had with it, I was fine with it being gone. 
It's not an experience that could POSSIBLY be recreated, anyway. (Not to 
say it couldn't be better, but that the novelty of all the characters 
working together isn't something that'd work in a 'sequel' imo)

+Ghabulous Ghoti Moving platforms would be removed if they were to go with

comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
I would hope that moving platforms aren't removed in a hypothetical switch. 
That would be awful. Smashville was considered one of the most balanced 
stages in Brawl. Only Dedede really did anything stupidly unbalanced with 
that moving platform, it kinda helped balance for most other matchups!

I wouldn't expect every stage to become legal from a hazard switch (the DK 
stage being a perfect example - not really a hazard, but still something 
that could never be used.) If they went with a general "if it hurts you, it 
can be turned off" mindset, that would solve most of my stage gripes. Stage 
transformations are another story. Some work just fine (the first two parts 
of Paper Mario), but some are just awful (the 3rd part). I could always 
dream about a "stage tier menu", allowing you to select which 
transformations appear, but that seems REALLY unlikely to me :P
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti Again, logistics are the main factor in deciding whether 
they'd put in a stage hazard toggle, not technical reasons like 
programming. They'd need to come up with a theme for it to work, like how 
they came up with the Omega theme for Sm4sh to represent the stages getting 
a 'final' counterpart to match Final Destination. Then there's the 
aforementioned reasoning of whether the dynamic versions would be neglected.

If I had to guess, a stage hazard toggle would entail more than just the 
hazards getting removed, but also every single dynamic element to them, 
like moving platforms and backgrounds, as well as unique features such as 
dual-planes and hidden rooms like in Tomodachi Life. There would be a cost 
to using the hazardless versions of stages, so you can't get the full 
experience on them.

There's always been a small (pretty much exclusively from the competitive 
crowd) section of fans who complain about the hazards in every single Smash 
game. Yellow Devil is the only one which is getting widespread criticism, 
but all the others are just nitpicking and shouldn't be taken seriously 
under any circumstances.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
If they decided to have a hazard switch in the next game, then I would hope 
they could just set up a simple "If-Else" statement for all the hazards 
when initially coding them. While it may be difficult to implement as an 
afterthought, if it was done from the beginning, it shouldn't be more work 
unless the programmers had no idea what they were doing.

I never raised my hopes. I think it's something that might happen in the 
future, and I'll be mildly disappointed if it does, but I don't think you 
need to worry about my hopes, if that's your concern. I'll still be content.

While the Devil is easily the most hated, I've seen not much less on the 
Flying Man. Ridley I've seen more than Metal Face, but I have seen both. 
And then there's others like Nabbit, the mom on Gamer, the Pokemon League, 
etc. They are much less mentioned, but I've seen or heard almost all of 
them.
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti Take some Game Design courses and you'll see what I'm 
talking about regarding the logistics behind a stage hazard toggle.

I don't doubt that competitive players want a hazard toggle, or at least 
the more reasonable ones, but the likeliness of one ever being implemented 
is low. For your own sake, don't get your hopes up.

The only complaint regarding the hazards in Sm4sh from casuals that I've 
seen is Yellow Devil, and while I personally don't have a problem with it 
(heck, I actually make use of its explosion upon defeat), I CAN understand 
why some people may not appreciate it when doing four player matches. That 
said, they wouldn't be complaining if Yellow Devil didn't appear so 
frequently or didn't take up so much real estate. Ridley and Metal Face 
aren't being met with much resentment, and not a single complaint about any 
of the other stage hazards has surfaced.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
I doubt the game would suffer in sales if there was an option to turn 
hazards off. I really don't think there would be anyone who would say 
"Nope, I can now choose to turn off hazards if I want. Not buying this 
game!" And I see what you are trying to say about the philosphy, but I 
disagree. Without the hazards, suddenly those stages can be used in an 
environment that supports the deepest and most complex fighter ever made.

I could tell you had a beef with competitive players. Look, the game still 
has plenty to make it stand apart. No other game has spacing and mindgames 
and combos quite like Smash Bros. It's still incredibly unique, even 
without items or hazards, it just becomes more controlled and less based 
around chance. The creators are under no obligation to please them, but IF 
they want to, that's what they have to do, and that's all I've been saying. 
Do you agree with that, or are you going to just argue for the sake of 
arguing?

A complaint isn't invalid for something like that. If it's a feature that 
someone wanted to see, it's perfectly valid for them to complain that it's 
missing, especially if the hazards are as large and intrusive as some in 
SSB4. This isn't only a competitive thing. I don't know what your 
experience with other people in this game is, but of the casuals I know, a 
very good chunk of them want to turn off bosses. Sure, a lot of them enjoy 
the bosses, but a lot find them super annoying.
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti It's not a question of liking it or not, rather, without 
something to make each stage play differently people wouldn't buy the game. 
Stage hazards are one such way to differentiate stages from each other 
beyond platform layouts, the latter of which not being a viable selling 
point. Basic game design entails forcing challenges on players, and 
allowing them to disable those challenges goes against that whole 
philosophy.

And no, people never ASKED for a new Smash game. Anticipation =/= asking.

That's why the competitive Smash scene gets so much disrespect, because 
they ignore everything which makes Smash stand apart from other fighters, 
like dual-plane battling. They're a commodity which self-imposed itself on 
the Smash fanbase, much like bronies did to MLP: FiM. The creators are 
under no obligation to provide for either, so if/when a stage hazard toggle 
doesn't come to fruition in Sm5sh, any complaints about it are 
automatically invalid.

I understand perfectly well that you enjoy it and only want to offer input 
as to how you think it'd be better. I'm just giving you a reality check.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
If people don't like it, then it's already a waste and they shouldn't spend 
time on it. If people do like it, then not everyone will turn off hazards 
and it won't be a waste. What's wrong with adding options?

No one's asking them to make the game? I'm sorry, but WHAT? Where were you 
the last few years, when people couldn't wait for a game that hadn't been 
announced yet? Everyone looks forward to the next Smash game. Of course 
people are asking them to make it.

There are a fair amount of stages that would be legal suddenly, though. 
Jungle Jijinks could even have an option to remove the barrels. And those 
stages have less to do with new rules and more to do with stalling, which 
is way to easy on both.

With your last paragraph, I must ask you again if you are actually reading 
what I am saying. I have said many times that I am happy with the game and 
that I love it as is. All I'm saying is that it would be slightly better 
with more options. If you have something against more options, that's your 
problem. I personally think it would make the game better. That doesn't 
mean I dislike it, and I want you to get that image out of your head. I've 
been greatly enjoying the game.
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti Not that it matters if Sm4sh is indeed his last one, which 
from his tone during interviews, it sounds like he's truly fed up with the 
fanbase's demands.

And no, that's not all the more reason to change it, because then all the 
work that went into programming the hazards goes to waste. That's what 
happened with the SSE in Brawl, their work going to waste when people 
uploaded the cutscenes online so people could watch them for free. And 
comparing a game to a meal is a bad analogy, because no one's asking for 
them to make the game; they're doing it because they want to.

A hazard toggle wouldn't even matter in the end, since most of the stages 
are already banned from tournament play just because they're either: A. 
Walk-offs, or B. Too big. And then there's stages like Jungle Hijinks and 
The Great Cave Offensive which have completely new rules, and that means 
instant banning.

Be happy for the stages that ARE legal in tournaments and accept the rest 
for what they are.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
My point with his opinion on the competitive side of the game was just that 
his opinions can be changed. That's all I need you to understand from that.

If everyone would neglect the hazards, then that's all the more reason to 
change it. A chef makes a meal the way it is asked, right? If a customer 
doesn't want a specific kind of sauce, they leave it out. If more people 
would neglect the hazarded versions, then that's all the more reason to 
have an option to remove them.

I never said there was a black and white division. It was a generalization. 
Of course there is grey areas, and I meant not to imply otherewise.
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti Except he didn't experience competitive play as dictated 
by the community, just the enthusiasm exuded by the crowd watching.

Regardless of what his opinions of it may be, it doesn't change the fact 
that adding a stage hazard toggle isn't as simple as making the decision. 
There's many logistical factors that need to be worked out alongside the 
technical ones before something, anything, can be implemented into a game. 
A stage hazard toggle can/will only be implemented if the developers can be 
guaranteed people won't neglect the hazarded versions.

And just so you know, there isn't a black and white division between 
casuals and competitors. I play with the full intention of winning, but I 
play for fun all the same. I seek to better myself at the game, but I still 
have no interest in tournaments.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon A casual is someone who isn't playing competitively. They 
are having fun. Usually, that style is associated with free-for-alls and 
gimmicky stages and items, but that's not necessary. A casual is just 
someone who isn't taking the game seriously, and they are entitled to play 
that way.

When thinking of a hazard toggle, I was thinking more along the lines of 
the item toggle and random stage select. A stage by stage menu.

Sakurai said he found competitive play boring and uninteresting. After the 
invitational, he said he had a new respect for it and even a mild interest. 
I saw this quoted on several websites back when it happened.
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti What makes you think those people are casuals? And just 
because some people might think Yellow Devil (not Ridley) is too intrusive 
doesn't mean they want a toggle for ALL stage hazards.

Also, Sakurai never said he hated competitive play. He just never paid any 
attention to it. And I sincerely doubt the invitational did anything to 
change his mind, and even if it did, not in the way you'd want, since the 
invitational itself wasn't set up like a typical tournament. For all he 
knows, the competitive scene will tolerate items being on, since he had no 
part in putting the invitational together.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon
I know he said he didn't want to make one, but he said he wanted to try to 
please the competitive crowd some more, and that's one of the biggest 
things he could do for them.

Changing his mind isn't a bad thing, because he's not perfect. Before the 
invitational, he HATED competitive play. He only tried to gear this game 
towards those players a bit more because it would sell more that way. The 
invitational changed his mind, and it's good that it did, because it opened 
his eyes. He doesn't realize perhaps how much people would love a hazard 
switch, both competitive and casual (most casuals I know HATE the stage 
bosses like Yellow Devil and Ridley.)
comments.author: Ghabulous Ghoti

comments.text:
+Ghabulous Ghoti Only because Sakurai agreed with them on his own, not 
because they changed his mind. A stage hazard toggle is something he's 
never alluded to under any circumstances, heck, I recall him saying he 
doesn't want to make Smash Bros like PSASBR in that regard.
comments.author: psychokinrazalon

comments.text:
+psychokinrazalon It worked for people who didn't like tripping or hitstun 
canceling.

I'm not saying that complaining will guarantee a change, but it will 
increase the odds of one. Sakurai isn't going to put time into a feature 
like that if he doesn't know people want one.

After glancing over this, I feel like I have to say a few things... First, 
I have played Smash Competitively before... I played mainly Brawl and 
Project M, but I quit later on because It just got boring for me... 
Anyways, Why are you guys arguing so much? I mean you can play smash anyway 
you want... That's why it's a great game! No need to hate eachover. I do 
have to say though, Derek, I dont feel like competitive is all that 
matters. I know that this is just my opinion, but I personally like a game 
that has some other stuff. I know you probably meant it as an opinion, but 
the way you typed made it seem like you were forcing it like it was a fact 
(As you  said "Competitive Smash is all that matters", not "Competitive 
Smash is all that matters to me"). Anways, here appears another question.

"What makes a Game Competitive?"

com·pet·i·tive  kəmˈpedədiv  
adjective
adjective competitive
of, relating to, or characterized by competition.
having or displaying a strong desire to be more successful than others.

Going by this you could say any game is competitive... In Mario Party you 
want to do better than others, so Mario Party is competitive! Also, In 
Smash Bros Brawl you want to do better than others so Brawl is competitive!

Honestly, all the Smash Games are competitive in one way or another... It's 
just what do people define as a truly competitive game...

comments.text:
+SupahGamers! I agree wholeheartedly with this. Smash run was really fun, 
and it was great to see a call back to City Trial, overall the mode was way 
to lacking to keep playing (I only play it once in a while now). Unlike 
City Trial, Smash run does not give you the options to change the amount of 
time, there is no free play of either the main map or the special smash 
modes, and there is no online. All of these missing features just ruin 
Smash Run, limiting it in too many ways. I can see the same happening with 
Smash tour. While it does look like a lot of fun, and the final smash where 
you fight with characters as your stocks is amazing, there are too many 
limitations to it as well. For one, it looks like you'll have to play it 
like six or seven times to get a good grasp on all the rules. Second, there 
is no online play, from what I've heard

captions.text:
It’s hard to believe that it’s been more
than 6-years since the last Smash Bros game?
*Crowd Reacts*

Okay, so maybe Super Smash Bros. 3DS literally
just came out a couple months ago, if you

want to be technical. And I Liked it. But
for me the, the true Super Smash Bros. experience

has always been about getting together with
friends and playing on a giant TV using a
proper controller.

Which is to say, Super Smash Bros. Wii U is
exactly what the doctor ordered.

So let’s cut to the chase: This game is
fun. Like, a ton of fun

And perhaps nothing exemplifies this better
than the addition of 8-Player Smash, which

doubles the amount of maximum participants
from past games. Now I know what some of you

are thinking: 4-Player Smash is often crazy
enough--8-Players must be chaos!

And sometimes it is, especially with a full
8 participants on a small arena, and items

turned on. And that’s certainly part of
the charm. But for those who take Smash Bros.

a little more, let’s say seriously, 8-Player
Smash--more often than not--was not only surprisingly

manageable, but also, to put into scientific
terms, a metric ass-ton of fun too.

And it helps that some of the stages were
seemingly created especially made for that

amount of players, with gigantic arenas like
Palutena's Temple and Kirby’s Great Cave

Offensive making for some truly unique-feeling
experiences. Hell, even the returning 75m

stage from Smash Bros. Brawl is actually worth-while
now thanks to a few tweaks and the addition

of more players. Although you might want to
make sure you’re playing on a larger TV

when on some of the bigger stages since the
characters can get pretty small when the camera

fully zooms out--thankfully I had almost no
problems keeping track of my character on
my 42” set

Now one drawback to 8-Player Smash is that
only about a third of the stages are available

if you’re playing with 7-8 people, and just
a handful more if you’re playing with 5-6

players. While I can understand the limitation
when playing with the maximum 8 people, the

amount of stages that become unplayable for
just 5 or 6 people feels far too restrictive.

It’s just a little disappointing that 2/3
of the stages become inaccessible simply for
adding a single person more

That issue aside, the selection here might
just be the best overall of any Smash Bros.

game. Of course, part of this is due to the
fact that some of my favorite stages from

past games return, such as Onett, Delfino
Plaza, and Halberd.

But the new stages too, really feel like they
go the extra mile, by being perhaps the most
dynamic--and exciting--they’ve ever been.

Take the new Mario Circuit for example, which
has you battling it out on various portions

of the the anti-gravity racetrack from Mario
Kart 8--during an active race! Which means

you can find yourself in all kinds of unusual
positions, such as having the racetrack directly

overhead, or even directly behind you, which
means you’ll have to dodge incoming racers
at all kinds of altitudes.

Then there’s Gamer, from Game & Wario. And
just like in that game, you’ll have to keep

an eye out for a patrolling mom in the background.
Because if you aren’t able to retreat to

the shadows in time, she’ll send you flying
if she catches you.

And in Wrecking Crew, you’ll actually be
able to destroy a building floor-by-floor--but

watch out for the falling barrels that can
trap you!

I really could go on and on about how fun
and unique most of the stages are, such as

how the travelling Wuhu Island stage is gorgeous
and each area you land in feels completely
unique--oh look, there I go again.

But with that said, not every stage is a home-run.
For example, as with the 3DS version, Dr.

Wily's Castle is basically ruined by the ever-present
Yellow Devil who interferes way too much with

the battle. And to a lesser extent, the same
goes for Pyrosphere and its Ridley boss too.

It’s honestly kind of baffling that, after
all these years, there still isn’t an option

to disable stage hazards such as these. And
this is coming from someone who generally

likes most stage hazards--but the option would
be nice, particularly in the case of those
two boss characters.

Despite that, the stage selection truly is
great overall. Such a sin Mushroom Kingdom

U...oh god, there I go again. I really can’t
stop! And it’s also the largest it’s ever

been, although it does lean just a little
too heavily on returning stages in order to

accomplish that feat, as Smash Bros Wii U
actually features fewer brand new stages than

Brawl did, which is a little disappointing.
Particularly when nearly everything else in
the game has has been cranked to the max.

Such as the plethora of modes beyond just
Smash matches. I mean, on top of pretty much

everything from Smash Bros. 3DS returning,
such as Classic Mode All-Star Mode, and Stadium

events, there are some cool new modes too,
such as Special Orders, which comes in two

forms: Master Orders and Crazy Orders. In
Master Orders, you pay an entrance fee to

partake in one of three randomly selected
challenges for a chance to win a prize. Whereas

Crazy Orders steps it up a notch, by requiring
a massive entrance fee in order to battle

in a series of challenges, with your reward
increasing after each one. But in order to

keep the reward, you’ll have to take down
Crazy Hand, who you can choose to battle at

any time. So this introduces a risk vs. reward
mechanic in trying to complete more challenges

in order to increase your reward before taking
down Crazy Hand to maximize your investment.

But here’s the catch--you only have 10-minutes
total which means you’ll have to move fast

in each challenge--oh, and your damage doesn’t
reset between rounds, making each subsequent

one a greater and greater risk. I found both
of the Special Order modes to be an interesting--and

engaging--diversion, although I’d be lying
if I said I didn’t find Crazy Orders to
be incredibly frustrating at times.

But my favorite mode, besides Smash battles
of course, has to be the return of Events

mode, which has you playing through a series
of unique challenges, complete with some flavorful

context. And some of the challenges are really
creative, -such as preventing an incoming

barrage of Game & Watches from touching the
stage. Oh, and there’s even a second set

of stages available exclusively for 2-player
co-op too. I found this mode to be a lot of

fun, and I couldn’t help wanting even more
Challenges after beating the 50+ solo ones.

Something else that returns from Brawl is
the Stage Creator, and it’s both better

and worse than before. The good news is you
can create pretty much any kind of platform

layout that you can imagine, thanks to the
ability to straight-up draw one of any shape

on the GamePad. The bad news is that the ability
to add interactive elements is extremely limited,

with moving platforms, cannons, and springs
being about the extent of it. The selection

is even more limited than Brawl’s Stage
Creator, which also had Ice Blocks, dropping
platforms, and Spikes that you could add.

Despite this, the editor is still pretty powerful,
as you can see here in my recreation of Hyrule

Castle from Smash Bros. 64. But as you can
also see, it also looks barely looks the part,

as the game only has 5 themes to choose from,
which makes all of the custom stages feel

very samey. And the process of creating a
stage isn’t exactly the most user-friendly

either. Why can’t I drag and drop platforms
around that I’ve already created, instead

of having to delete them and recreate them
somewhere else? Oh, and though there is a

grid you can overlay on the canvas to more
accurately create your stage, the lines aren’t

actually all thick enough for them to be rendered
on the GamePad’s low-resolution screen accurately,

making them harder to use than they should
be. With that said, it’s still a neat feature
that allows for a lot of potential,

But perhaps the game’s biggest new mode
is something called Smash Tour, which is basically

the Wii U’s version of Smash Run. Except
this this time, you power up your fighter--or

fighters in this case--by collecting power-ups
on a board game. And not just power-ups, but

fighters too, which represent the characters
& amount of lives you’ll have in the final

battle at the end of the game. But that’s
not the only battle, as you’ll engage in

a variety of Special Matches throughout the
game whenever you encounter someone else on

the board, which allows you to steal their
fighters in turn.

It’s a neat idea--particularly the Final
Battle, which really should be its own mode

as I love the idea of being able to play as
different characters within the same Match.

But here’s my problem: the whole thing is
nearly incomprehensible. The game’s director

even said himself that it’s difficult to
convey in words--and he’s not kidding. It’s

unintuitive, unnecessarily complicated, and
visually confusing. There is just a ridiculous

amount of stuff happening at once-- one after
another. In a single round, you’ll have

random pre-turn item drops, split-screen item
usage, to the simultaneous dice-rolling and

real-time player-movement, which is accompanied
by whatever items you and your opponents decided

to use--such as being launched all over the
map. And if anyone encountered anyone else

on the board, that means you’ll then have
a Smash Bros battle too, where even more item
effects will take place.

Basically, I think I finally understand how
my Dad feels when he watches me play a normal

round of Smash Bros, in that I had no idea
what was happening. Now granted, after a few

games, Smash Tour finally did start to make
some sense but it never ended up clicking

for me. The entire thing felt too chaotic
and random--as if nothing I did really mattered.

Add this to to the fact that it’s nearly
impossible to explain to your friends in a

succinct manner while making sense, and you
end up with a mode that I found to be more

trouble to play than its worth. I mean, why
would we bother with Smash Tour when we could

just play Smash instead where we’re guaranteed
a good time?

And it’s actually for that exact reason
that my indifference to Smash Tour doesn’t

really matter. While I would have obviously
liked to have enjoyed it more, it’s an optional

mode that doesn’t detract from the rest
of the game at all.

And thankfully, as I said before, the core
gameplay in Super Smash Bros. Wii U to be

fantastic. The roster of characters is huge
and fun to explore, the controls feel fantastic,

and I can’t imagine playing a future Smash
Bros. game in which 8-Player Smash isn’t

an option. Oh, and then there’s the Amiibo
support, which allows you to power-up a custom

fighter to the point that it becomes a real
menace on the battlefield.

And I haven’t even talked about the game’s
gorgeous visuals--which run at 1080p and a

rock-solid 60fps. I seriously only experienced
a handful of instance of slowdown in over

70-hours with the game, and always under some
pretty extraordinary circumstances. With the

odd exception of the pause screen, which almost
always slows down when you zoom in close.

Oh, and then there’s the game’s excellent
soundtrack, which is hundreds of songs deep,

including a ton of fantastic remixes of both
new and classic Nintendo songs. Just listen
to this:

Pretty great, right? And that’s just 1 of
over 400 songs in the game.

So clearly, there’s a lot to do in Smash
Bros. Wii U. And while not every mode was

a home-run for me, they also didn’t need
me to be. I expect one thing and one thing

only from Smash Bros: and that’s to have
a Smashing good time with friends--and Smash
Bros. Wii U delivers that in spades.

So as you can probably guess, I Loved Super
Smash Bros. Wii U. It’s simply a blast to

play with friends...as long as you’re not
playing Smash Tour.

However, I should mention that online multiplayer
was not functional at the time of this review.

Now I realize for many of you, that will likely
be a huge component of the game, so rest assured

we’ll be covering it in the future. But
for me personally, since I’ve always found

Smash Bros. to be best locally with friends
in the same room, the online functionality--and

whether it even works well--has no bearing
on me loving this game. But with that said,

we will be covering its real-world performance
as soon as we’re able to.

Thanks for watching and make sure to stay-tuned
to GameXplain.com for more reviews and other
things on Super Smash Bros. Wii U too.

title: Super Smash Bros. Wii U - Video Review
